info.game_comments:
1998 Boston Week game 5.
From the Wang Center for the Performing Arts in Boston, Massachusetts.

(1, 1).clue: As the Planters icon knows, everybody loves these; in 1996 Americans ate 2 billion pounds of them

(3, 1).clue: He hammered a career total of 755 major league home runs

(4, 1).clue: A "long" one is 2,240 pounds, a "short" one is 2,000

(5, 1).clue: With a funnel more than a mile wide, one of the largest of these occured March 18, 1925 & killed 695 people

(6, 1).clue: Yogi Berra observed that in this sport, "You don't know nothing"

(1, 2).clue: Whether you like it hot or cold, borscht is a Russian soup made from these root vegetables

(4, 2).clue: Whether you hide your light under it or not, it's equal to 35.24 liters

(5, 2).clue: It's a snowstorm with winds past 30 knots, below normal temperatures & visibility reduced to 1/8 of a mile

(6, 2).clue: Spanish for "nothing", it's found in the expression meaning "you're welcome"

(1, 3).clue: If you like it kosher, He'Brew is "The Chosen" type of this beverage & "Exile Never Tasted So Good"

(3, 3).clue: This scandalous author married June Mansfield on June 1, 1924

(4, 3).clue: This international standard is equal to approximately 3,281 feet

(5, 3).clue: Body part associated with the center of the image seen here (hurricane)

(6, 3).clue: In a 1975 musical, Diana sings "Nothing" at an audition for this title group

(1, 4).clue: If you like it hot, use this brand of sauce made with red peppers, vinegar & salt mined on Avery Island

(2, 4).clue: Ask Timon how this tomb in Athens differs from America's & he'll tell you the guards don't wear pants
(2, 4).correct response: The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier

(3, 4).clue: Give me this man who was governor of Virginia from 1776 to 1779 & again from 1784 to 1786

(4, 4).clue: Hold your breath!  If you traveled 20,000 leagues under the sea, you'd go 60,000 of these

(5, 4).clue: Produced by thunderstorm clouds, these lumps of ice bigger than 5mm are classified as hydrometeors

(6, 4).clue: U.S. president whose middle initial "S" stood for nothing

(1, 5).clue: Our writers like this cereal grain whether it's in succotash or bourbon

(2, 5).clue: Timon avoids this ancient market because he's afraid of the crowds

(3, 5).clue: With works like "Elements", he flowered as the resident poet on "Laugh-In"

(4, 5).clue: What we Yanks would call a trillion, the Brits would call this

(5, 5).clue: This "great" area on Jupiter is a violent storm first discovered in 1664

(6, 5).clue: "Nothing" is the answer to "Does a dog have Buddha nature?", one of these paradoxes

(1, 1).clue: Revere dressed up as an Indian to take part in this event of December 16, 1773

(3, 1).clue: In 1994 this 1970s Jim Garner series was revived in a TV movie

(5, 1).clue: Irving was visited in Spain by this young fan & future "Song of Hiawatha" poet

(1, 2).clue: Boston's Museum of Fine Arts has an impressive collection of Revere's work in this metal

(2, 2).clue: Ludwig saw words not as labels but as these, like hammers or screwdrivers

(3, 2).clue: NBC's top show of the 1982-83 season, it suited Mr. & Mrs. America to a "T"

(4, 2).clue: In 1956 this versatile actor starred in "Davy Crockett And The River Pirates"

(5, 2).clue: In a slump, Irving went to Scotland where this novelist encouraged him to keep writing

(1, 3).clue: For a time, Revere practiced this trade, making devices "Of real use in speaking & eating"

(2, 3).clue: Ludwig believed logical propositions function as these, so they're worth 1,000 words

(3, 3).clue: Cannell's title pairs include "Hardcastle And McCormick" & "Tenspeed And" him

(4, 3).clue: She was the "other woman" in Prince Charles & Princess Diana's divorce

(5, 3).clue: In 1811, as a lobbyist in Washington, Irving became a favorite of this first lady

(1, 4).clue: On his famous ride, Revere & this man met up with Samuel Prescott before attempting to reach Concord

(3, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Mitzi Kapture)  For 5 years I played Lt. Rita Lee Lance on this Cannell series on USA Network

(4, 4).clue: On FOX TV from '90 - '93, this title character couldn't "lose"

(5, 4).clue: During this duelist's 1807 trial for treason, Irving struck up a friendship with his daughter, Theodosia

(1, 5).clue: Massacre victim seen here in an engraving by Paul Revere

(3, 5).clue: Richard Grieco graduated from this Cannell series to his own Cannell series -- "Booker"

(4, 5).clue: He directed vibrant films like "Midnight Express", "Pink Floyd -- The Wall" & "Evita"

(5, 5).clue: This self-made millionaire fur trader asked Irving to write a book based on his exploits

(0, 0).clue: Written in 1953 & set in the late 17th c., this play takes place about 16 miles northeast of where we are right now
